tweets.content:
10 On-chain Trading Rules 

Not advice, but writing this more as a reminder to myself after many painful losses, fumbles, roundtrips. 

1. Your no1 priority as a trader is to protect your capital, market might be hot doesn't mean you let yourself fomo-ing in plays that will rinse your money. 

2. Detach all your emotions out of your portfolio number, adjust your risk so that no loss should fuck up ur mental - don't oversize trying to " make it", slow and steady will win the race even tho that race might be boring but it will never zero you out.

3. Trade the attention, when you see a bubble forming, don't hesitate to add fuel into fire, the early birds are the ones who get the worms . In trading, brutal truth is the crowd is your exit liquidity - not your ally, always sells when every1 fomo-ing at the top.

Crowded trade never plays out well 

- example: during BNB euphoria, early bridgers printed while everyone else was still stuck on Sol. Narrative doesn't care about a few seconds delay in txs.

4. Don't overtrade, the more u clicks, the less you think, as quality over quantity always. 

5. Laziness kills greatness, instead, spend time to observer everything, do DD on every runner u miss, and reflect on every trades you executed poorly.

6. Cutting loss early, don't let the "BREAK EVEN" mindset to lock your capital, what goes down 30% can go down another 50%, and what already down 50% can go down another 80%.

7. Focus on what you can control, accept the risk of nature of trading which is uncertainty, nobody can predict the next candle so learn to focus only ur entry, ur size, ur exit.

8. Monitor everything, don't sit and do nothing

> Any vamps? (better ticker, image, or tech?)
> Any valid FUD?
> Any interesting wallets accumulating?
> How‚Äôs the sentiment shifting?

9. Stay humble in winning streaks, but confident in losing streaks. Pride. ego, and self-pitty are ur biggest enemies. The market humbles the proud, but it also never rewards the hopeless.

10. Be comfortable sitting on their hands, for no trades is also a trade. Best traders i know only bid when good set-ups appear, and stay patient most of the time

Stay disciplined. Show up daily. The rest takes care of itself. Your success already written among the stars.

tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
The PvP happening in the trenches right now is often senseless and adapting can be incredibly difficult.

There are so many possibilities to consider:

1) New pair gets vamped by a better coin due to an error (wrong image, ticker, name, etc)
2) New pair gets vamped for no reason
3) New pair gets vamped by a more creative concept
4) First deploy re-vamps the better coin afterwards for no reason
5) People rotate between the first deploy and the better coin three times
6) The actual OG vamps for no reason
7) The actual OG vamps because it's a better coin or already has an established community
8) People buy the redeployed new pair for no reason and the OG does nothing or gets incinerated
9) Coin vamps because it's a community
10) Pump gets vamped by bonk because it's a USD1 or other related narrative
11) Bonk gets vamped by pump because people randomly decide they don't like it
12) Coin gets vamped by a relevant dev (fartcoin, useless, etc)
13) Coin gets vamped by fee donations / better dev
14) SOL gets vamped by BNB or vice versa

Then you have to predict whether or not people will choose a final winner (they usually don't and everything slow bleeds to zero)

What I hate about this is that there's no way to always choose the correct coin with logic. There are so many factors to contemplate that most people completely abandon their own thinking and buy whatever the important KOLs choose.

(If you're one of these people and are unprofitable, what are you doing? Do you want to be exit liquidity? Do your own research and formulate your own opinion about every single coin you buy. Stop being lazy and try to front run people instead of waiting for them to buy or shill it to you.)

Requiring popular wallets or big streamers to promote a narrative unfortunately creates a huge element of luck that kills most forms of strategy. Sometimes the more creative coin wins, sometimes the OG wins, and sometimes the obviously correct coin completely loses. There are no strict guidelines you can use to win the PvP every time - trading is all about attention and the market rotates FAST.

What I've learned is that every situation is unique. In order to stay consistent, you have to be open-minded and adapt quickly to each new scenario.

- Don't just base your thesis on what happened last time
- Only think about your current trade and what catalysts could bring eyes to it right now
- Stay selective and don't oversize into <100k toppers
- Remove all of your personal bias, don't cope hold, and don't be stubborn when your coin is proven wrong
- If you don't see a clear win, it's often better to stay sidelined
- Focus on PvE narratives

This thread was more of a note to self but I figured some people might find it insightful üôÇ

tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
Take notes for the final phase of this bull market

1/ Don‚Äôt DCA in.
Dollar-cost-averaging works early in a cycle. At the end, time is against you. If you‚Äôre late, you need conviction bets.

2/ DCA out.
On the way up, scale out. Don‚Äôt dream about selling the exact top ‚Äî nobody times it perfectly. Secure wins instead.

3/ Focus on winners.
Cut dead weight. Don‚Äôt waste emotional energy on bags that never recovered. Winners compound. Losers drain you.

4/ Don‚Äôt lock tokens.
Staking rewards look good until your tokens are stuck while the bull ends. Flexibility is worth far more than a few extra percent of yield. Liquidity is freedom.

5/ Rotate less.
This late in the game, chasing every narrative leads to overtrading. Sit on your hands. You can‚Äôt catch them all. Accept missing some.

6/ This is a marathon, not a sprint.
The people who make life-changing gains are the ones who preserve capital into the next cycle. Survive first. Wealth is built over multiple cycles.

7/ Don‚Äôt baghold exit coins.
When it‚Äôs time to leave, don‚Äôt wait for tokens that ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt pump yet.‚Äù Some coins never pump again. Hope is not a strategy.

8/ Cash out regularly.
Don‚Äôt wait for ‚Äúthe big exit.‚Äù Take profits steadily. Build trust with your bank ‚Äî you‚Äôll need them for bigger moves outside of crypto.

9/ Concentrate your bets.
Over-diversification kills upside. A 100x on $5 won‚Äôt change your life. Position sizing matters. Focus on high-conviction plays.

10/ Remember volatility.
Near the top, swings are violent. Don‚Äôt let green candles make you greedy or red candles shake you out. Stick to your plan.

11/ Narratives move fast.
AI, gaming, RWA, memecoins ‚Äî narratives rotate weekly. Don‚Äôt chase them all. Stick to a few strong themes and ride them with discipline.

12/ Think outside crypto.
Use this cycle to set up for the next phase of your life. Real estate, businesses, equities ‚Äî crypto should fund your future, not be your only future.

13/ Know when enough is enough.
Greed kills more than fear. Have a number where you‚Äôll say ‚ÄúI made it‚Äù and commit to it.

14/ This isn‚Äôt your last shot.
Cycles repeat. If you miss this one, there will be another. Stay liquid, stay disciplined, stay alive.

15/ The bull makes you rich. The bear keeps you rich.
Don‚Äôt blow it all just because the market feels invincible right now. Discipline is more powerful than luck.

Let‚Äôs make the best out of itü´°
tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
Some quotes from Reminiscences of a Stock Operator.

"There is the plain fool, who does the wrong thing all the time, but there is the Wall Street fool, who thinks he must trade all the time. No man can always have adequate reasons for buying or selling stocks daily or sufficient knowledge to make his play an intelligent play."

"One of the most helpful things that anybody can learn is to give up trying to catch the last eighth or the first. These two are the most expensive eighths in the world."

"I have often said that to buy on a rising market is the most comfortable way of buying stocks."

"It never was my thinking that made the big money for me. It always was my sitting. Got that? My sitting tight! It is no trick at all to be right on the market.

You always find lots of early bulls in bull markets and early bears in bear markets. I've known many men who were right at exactly the right time, and began buying or selling stocks when prices were at the very level which should show the greatest profit. And their experience invariably matched mine that is, they made no real money out of it. Men who can both be right and sit tight are uncommon.

I found it one of the hardest things to learn.But it is only after a stock operator has firmly grasped this that he can make big money.‚Äù

"A stock operator has to fight a lot of expensive enemies within himself."

"If a stock doesn‚Äôt act right don‚Äôt touch it; because, being unable to tell precisely what is wrong, you cannot tell which way it is going. No diagnosis, no prognosis. No prognosis, no profit."

"The trend is evident to a man who has an open mind and reasonably clear sight, for it is never wise for a speculator to fit his facts to his theories."

"What does a man do when he sets out to make the stock market pay for a sudden need? Why, he merely hopes. He gambles. He runs much greater risks than he would if he were speculating intelligently, in accordance with opinions or beliefs logically arrived at."

"It cost me millions to learn that another dangerous enemy to a trader is his susceptibility to the urgings of a magnetic personality when plausibly expressed by a brilliant mind."

"Do you wish to gamble blindly in the hope of getting a great big profit or do you wish to speculate intelligently and get a smaller but much more probable profit?"

"It was the kind of market in which not even a skunk could make a scent."

"Of all speculative blunders there are few greater than trying to average a losing game. Always sell what shows you a loss and keep what shows you a profit."

tweets.content:
KLED Ai Thesis

Just like NFTs, the early days of on-chain AI narrative were filled w/ a lot of noise but now when the dust has settled, only quality AI projects managed to survive, and $KLED is one of them, and prolly the best one out there.

KLED is a decentralized data marketplace in which users can sell their personal data - such as photos, videos, documents (text, audio,...)

Biggest tech corporations (Google, Facebook, TikTok) ‚Äúpay‚Äù with free services in exchange for your personal data so they could monetize by personalized ads

Ok, now, imagine u could actually monetize ur data instead of giving it away for free - oh wait, you don't have to imagine anymore, just download KLED AI on Appstore and start selling

So much higher

tweets.content:
When sniping, make sure to make ur Bribe Fee > Priority Fee so Jito Validator gonna help u get first txs on that block 

Also increase slippage to around 50%~70% to increase the likelihood to get in ( MEV protection off) 

+) Priority Fee = paid to all Solana validators for faster processing of your TX in the queue.

+) Bribe Fee (Jito Tip) = paid specifically to Jito block producers for blockspace favoritism.

Remember to use @BloomTrading as always:

tweets.author: solvenant
solvenant

tweets.content:
III. Psychology - 10 RULES 

1. Journal Every Trade - Track your reasoning, entry, exit, emotions - have some respect for the game and for urself if you really want to be better

2. Kill the FOMO - if you feel rushed- u are likely late. Best execution comes from patience, not chasing 

3. Respect Risk Management:
+) NEVER ever FULLPORT 
+) NEVER risk so much that u lose sleep over it
+) NEVER risk so much that 1 LOSS wipe out ur ability to trade tmr 

4. Big win or Big loss, ur mind should always be stoic, be calm - don't get hyped up like a monkey on drugs or sad as if u likely to die tmr

5. Don't Overtrade - the more u clicks, the less you think - Quality >> Quantity

6. Zoom Out: One bad day doesn't mean you will lose in the next 1000 days

7. Buy into Early Speculation - be aggressive when others afraid to do so, and sell on their heads when they FOMO in

8. Stay Humble in Winning Streaks - Pride and Ego are ur biggest enemies - market will humble u if you don't humble urself 

9. Accepting Uncertainty - Focus on what u can control - ur entry, ur size, ur exit - u will never have the complete picture of a coin - learn to act with incomplete data

10. Be Comfortable Doing Nothing - best traders I know sit on their hands most of the time - they only bid when good set-ups appear

tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
6. Devving 

Ask yourself 5 questions and ALWAYS remembers these 5 RULES

Questions? 

1) Is it a good narrative?
2) Which Launchpad should it be on? 
3) Am i gonna support this long-term or short-term?
4) How much supply u want to control? 
5) How much u willing to spend for marketing like KOL' calls, DEX, Art + Vids, Booosts?

Rules

1) Tier Your Dev Effort 
- Tier 1: Full branding, Twitter push, paid shills, roadmap 
- Tier 2: Decent branding, some shills, basic expenses like Dex, or Boost
- Tier 3: Lazy, NO art, NO push, pure gamble

2) Networking , form a dev team, ask people to be onboarded with you, cross-check to see if u have things like DEX, banner ready before launch

3) Don't overspend to inject liquidity in to support the chart - I myself lost 50 SOL on a 70k toppers and 60 SOL on a 100k toppers just trying to push a coin because im involved in it  - DONT be ME 

4) If your launches catch Organic bids, and the trenches really like ur idea, let it run high with ur supply hold tight - don't nuke it, be gentle and trim out slowly 

5) Be a good DEV, don't be a Faggot Rugger

tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
3. High Market-cap Conviction Sizing - 10 Rules

1) Never Size without a GOOD Thesis - if u can't explain the narra in 2-3 sentences on WHY the play is good, size = 0 

2) Entry is important - being aggress with your entry can save urself from a lot of weak FUD, shakeouts, and self-impulsive stupid thoughts 

3) Scale in, Don't YOLO - DCA slowly thru platform like @JupiterExchange 

4) Short - term PA doesn't matter as much if the narrative is good, it will run, just HODL if u see the vision !!! S/O to @risk100x 

5) What confluences from fellow traders who's in the same coin with you - also seek others ' opinion on it as well, especially from bearish viewers to see if it is valid or nah?

6) What is my exit strategy?
+) What is my TP -   2x or 3x or 5x? 
+) What is my SL // -20% or -50%? 

7) How much of my port should I size in (15-20% is the ideal number but sometimes 35%-50% even 70% is still acceptable) 

8) Never marry your bags, cut or be cut - we can't force the market accept to accept our convictions!

9) Tie your Conviction to Data, NOT Hope
+) Are whales buying ?
+) Narrative sentiment is good? 
+) Alpha leader aka Bluechip of a narrative? 

--> The More boxxes it ticks, the Better it is 

10) Your conviction should Match with informational sauce 

+) If your info is second-hand or public, then size small
+) If you have insider info only shared privately between fnfs, size bigger
tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
2) For mid-cap trading - u need to be able to identify is it GOOD or BAD (narrative wise) 

Ask yourself these 10 questions

1. Has this similar idea been launched before, if so how high did it go? 

2. Is it the beta or alpha? 

3. What launch pad is the best for it - becareful of vamping attempts -is it should be on @BagsApp or @pumpdotfun or @bonk_fun  or even @believeapp ? 

4. Is this token bundled? 

5. Who is the dev? Which FnF launched this? Are they strong or weak? 

6. Are there any tracked wallets in this? 

7. If it is AI coins, do DD as fast as u can on domain age, website, dev background, github, affiliated previous projects, etc

+) is the dev doxxed ? 
+) what is his/her LinkeIn ? 
+) what are his/her mutual smart followers? 

8. If it is community coins

+) is the cult strong ? 
+) is the meme funny ? 
+) who is the leader of the X comm ? 

9. If it is a TikTok coin, ask youself
+) How viral is it ?
+) Check # on tiktok to see the views ?

10. " AM I EARLY? OR LATE? - WHO WILL BUY AFTER ME? "

tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
Reverse Psychology in Trading

Instead of learning from Trader A, Trader B, or Trader C, ask yourself a few simple questions: 

‚ÄúWhat would a BAD trader do? ‚Äú

+) A bad trader would top blast out of FOMO volume without having done DD or a clear exit plan

+) A bad trader often got married to his bags and refuse to cut loss early: from -15% to -40% to -80%

+) A bad trader doesn‚Äôt reflect on his mistakes and execution, either he is too lazy to do so or he doesn‚Äôt even bother 

+) A bad trader could sometimes hit a lucky play once in a while but eventually he will end up getting rinsed back to ZERO because of poor risk management.

Instead of trying to be a good trader, avoid being a bad one can be the first step towards growth.
tweets.author: solvenant

tweets.content:
Your no1 priority as a trader is to protect ur chips - you can‚Äôt control the price action - but u can control ur sizing, ur exit plan, ur decision to buy or sidelined.

The game is getting harder everyday, it is not easy to adapt fully but the best thing to do is wait & watch until u feel confidently enough to fire ur bullets. 

Market is hot doesn‚Äôt mean you have to force trades and get burnt.
